Abandoned

in favor of https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/76545

The CI failure is on trunk as well:

```
$ git checkout HEAD~
$ ./scripts/validate_configs.py
/root/openbmc/entity-manager/./scripts/validate_configs.py:142: DeprecationWarning: jsonschema.RefResolver is deprecated as of v4.18.0, in favor of the https://github.com/python-jsonschema/referencing library, which provides more compliant referencing behavior as well as more flexible APIs for customization. A future release will remove RefResolver. Please file a feature request (on referencing) if you are missing an API for the kind of customization you need.
  resolver = jsonschema.RefResolver(base_uri, schema)
```

Nevermind, it was a legit failure, fixed by removing `"ValueType"` which was redundant with `"SensorType"` anyway.

The `validate_configs.py` script hides error messages unless you omit `-k`

Why not?  There is a single i2c bus coming off the HMC board for both the EEPROM and the SMBPBI interface.  The SMBPBI address is specified by the HMC itself.  I'm pretty sure that whatever bus/address we use to find the EEPROM is also the same bus for the SMBPBI.  Therefore, we should be able to make at least the basic SMBPBI information common across all users of the board.

Hmmmmm ok, I mean I'm happy to add this to nvidia_hmc.json, I just wouldn't guarantee that it will work for the next user that comes along.

Compare this specification in the downstream Nvidia repository:

https://github.com/NVIDIA/openbmc/blob/0a389de055e3b08110ac6bb9c80e653873fd2889/meta-nvidia/meta-prime/meta-graceblackwell/meta-gb200nvl/meta-bmc/recipes-phosphor/configuration/entity-manager/files/HMC.json#L5-L6

```
                "Address": "0x4f",
                "Bus": 2,
```

And then the address and bus from a live Catalina BMC:

```
xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.Satellite interface -         -                          -
.Address                                    property  t         79                         emits-change
.Bus                                        property  t         13                         emits-change
```

So, yes you're correct about the address, but what about the bus, that's different right? That part
depends on which bus we connect the HMC board to on the BMC part.

oh wait, I didn’t read your comment carefully enough, yeah I think you’re correct, the fru eeprom should be on the same bus. let me check that again, if that’s the case then yeah I’ll just move this to nvidia_hmc.json.

Yeah ok, confirmed it's the same bus. I'll redo this

```
xyz.openbmc_project.FruDevice       interface -         -                    -
.ADDRESS                            property  u         87                     emits-change
.BOARD_LANGUAGE_CODE                property  s         "25"                 emits-change    emits-change
.BUS                                property  u         13                   emits-change
```
Ok: I moved the configuration object to nvidia_hmc.json, and I'm using the "$bus" from the HMC FRU EEPROM.
(I wrote about this later, but this is the problematic aspect of what you've done.)
Acknowledged

This isn't a separate FRU from the "real" HMC.  What you've done here will create two separate inventory objects (in entity-manager) which will show up as two different FRUs in EM (and eventually in Redfish).  This isn't what we want.

Well, to be clear, this configuration file will not create 2 different FRUs, it will create 1. But because there is another configuration file that matches on the HMC FRU (nvidia_hmc.json), it will also create an object. That was actually my intent.

The reason I was doing this is because the bus address varies depending on the SCM part, so I was trying to make a config object that will provide this additional SMBPBI information, separate from the core HMC information (that provides the IP address).

I also don't like the fact that it's a separate object, but I'm not sure how else to add Catalina-specific information about the HMC. I could add it to the SCM object, if that would be preferable, and remove the HMC condition?

> That was actually my intent.

This will produce an incorrect dbus and Redfish tree.  We shouldn't have a single fru represented twice.

> make a config object 

Adding a new exposes record would be your path to do that, not making a completely new file.

Add your new stanza to the existing HMC config file.

Got it, moved the config object to nvidia_hmc.json, now the SMBPBI device shows up under the HMC object path.

I took the liberty of refactoring the object structure in this change significantly, after learning a little more about the schemas.
Hey Ed, I moved the configuration to the nvidia_hmc.json configuration file, is this issue resolved?
Done
yes, you've resolved this.

We explicitly used this before:

```
    "Probe": "xyz.openbmc_project.FruDevice({'BOARD_PRODUCT_NAME': 'P4764', 'BOARD_MANUFACTURER': 'NVIDIA'})",
```

If you just do "Product Name" you don't know which version of the HMC it is, so you can end up having the wrong config loaded anyhow.

Oh ok, yeah I saw that the real version is using the name explicitly but it seemed like overkill to be that specific. It's also not as obvious when reading the inventory busctl output to tell what it's supposed to be.
Fixed, just using the Probe condition already present in nvidia_hmc.json now.

Note: I've refactored the configuration schema in the latest change.

I removed the SmbusPostBoxInterface schema and just replace it with inline SmbusPostBox objects, which is closer to the downstream design. It makes it easier to find the objects, because entity-manager won't do the object-index-in-interface-name thing to create an array, all the objects will have the xyz.openbmc_project.Configuration.SmbusPostBox interface.

Peter, please help to review https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/76545

We can't merge all 3 the rust implementation, your implementation you pushed last night, and the one Aushim pushed a few days ago (which is the Nvidia reference implementation with minor naming changes)

Lets consolidate on one that works for everyone and move forward.

Yeah agreed, I'm totally fine with the Nvidia reference implementation. I was just posting the Rust and C++ coroutine variants to gauge interest and/or try to figure out how to onboard more quickly (this is the first time I'm actually working on these dbus daemons).

So you guys are totally fine to just push the Nvidia reference in. But it needs entity-manager changes too right? Those weren't included afaict. I'm also fine with just merging the downstream Nvidia reference configuration schema too.

I really don't care that much about the way any of this code is written, I just want to see if merged. I'm still trying to figure out how much flexibility *maintainers* will allow for in these things.
